content.text: It's 11pm on a Sunday and your house has lost all power. Or you've just discovered a burning smell from a socket. You need an emergency electrician â€” but how much will it cost? In 2026, UK emergency electricians charge Â£80-Â£180 per hour depending on time and location, plus a call-out fee of Â£60-Â£150. This guide breaks down exactly what you'll pay and, crucially, when it's worth paying emergency rates vs waiting until morning.

Emergency Electrician Costs 2026 (UK)
*Standard daytime work often has no separate call-out fee OR call-out fee covers first hour. Always confirm before booking.
What Is an Emergency Electrician Call-Out Fee?
The **call-out fee** covers the electrician traveling to your property, often outside normal hours. In 2026:

items: **Weekday emergency:** Â£60-Â£100 call-out
**Weekend/evening:** Â£70-Â£120 call-out
**Bank holiday/night:** Â£90-Â£150 call-out

content.text: Most electricians include the first hour in the call-out fee. After that, you pay the hourly rate. Example:

Is It a TRUE Emergency? (Save Money by Waiting)
Emergency electricians exist for genuine safety risks. But many 'emergencies' can safely wait until daytime rates. Here's how to tell:
Call Emergency Electrician NOW (Safety Risk)

items: **Burning smell from sockets/switches** â€” Risk of fire
**Sparks or arcing from any electrical point** â€” Immediate danger
**Exposed live wires** (e.g., damaged cable showing copper)
**Electric shock from appliance** â€” Faulty appliance or wiring
**Total power loss in winter** â€” With young children or elderly at risk
**Crackling/buzzing from consumer unit** â€” Potential fire hazard
**Water entering electrics** (flood/leak) â€” Electrocution risk
**Tripped RCD that won't reset** â€” May indicate dangerous fault

content.text: **Action:** Turn off power at the main switch if safe to do so. Call emergency electrician.
Can Wait Until Morning (Book Standard Rate)

items: **Power to one room/circuit lost** â€” If rest of house OK
**Single light not working** â€” Use alternative lighting
**Socket not working** (no burning smell) â€” Use another socket
**Tripped circuit, cause identified** â€” E.g., overloaded extension, can avoid overnight
**Lights flickering (no other symptoms)** â€” May be supply issue, monitor
**Doorbell/outdoor lights not working** â€” Non-essential systems

content.text: **Potential saving:** Waiting 8 hours until 8am can save you Â£100-Â£250 for the same repair.
âœ“ Smart move: If you can isolate the fault (turn off that circuit at the consumer unit) and live without it overnight, book a morning appointment and save 40-60%.
What Affects Emergency Electrician Cost?
1. Time of Day/Week
Emergency rates follow this hierarchy (cheapest to most expensive):

items: **Cheapest:** Weekday daytime (Â£45-Â£65/hr)
**Mid-range:** Weekday evening or weekend day (Â£75-Â£120/hr)
**Expensive:** Weekend night or weeknight 11pm-8am (Â£100-Â£160/hr)
**Most expensive:** Bank holidays, Christmas, New Year (Â£120-Â£180/hr)

content.text: 2. Location (West Midlands vs London)
3. Qualification & Registration

items: **Apprentice/improver:** Â£40-Â£55/hr (shouldn't work unsupervised)
**Qualified electrician:** Â£75-Â£120/hr (emergency)
**Part P registered (NICEIC/NAPIT):** Â£80-Â£140/hr (can self-certify)
**Approved contractor + 24/7 service:** Â£100-Â£160/hr (premium)

4. Job Complexity
**Simple fix** (tripped breaker, loose wire): 30 mins-1 hour = Â£80-Â£150 total
**Diagnostic required** (fault finding): 1-2 hours + repair time = Â£200-Â£400+
**Major fault** (multiple circuits, hidden damage): 3-6 hours = Â£400-Â£900+
How to Reduce Emergency Electrician Costs
Before Calling

items: **Check your consumer unit** â€” Is a circuit breaker tripped? Try resetting it once
**Identify the fault** â€” Which circuit is affected? (helps electrician diagnose faster)
**Turn off the faulty circuit** â€” If you can isolate it, reduce urgency
**Check with neighbours** â€” Power cut might be network-wide (call power company, not electrician)
**Remove obstacles** â€” Clear access to consumer unit, loft, affected areas

content.text: When Booking

items: **Get a quote over the phone** â€” Describe the fault, get estimate
**Ask about call-out fee** â€” Is it fixed or hourly?
**Confirm hourly rate** â€” Emergency rate should be clear upfront
**Ask about first-hour rule** â€” Does call-out cover first hour?
**Get ETA** â€” How quickly can they attend? (faster often = more expensive)

content.text: Smart Alternatives

items: **Wait until morning** â€” Save 40-60% on same job (if safe)
**Book first appointment (8am)** â€” Often cheaper than late evening
**Use your regular electrician** â€” Loyalty customers sometimes get better rates
**Check home insurance** â€” Emergency electrical cover may be included

content.text: Emergency Electrician Red Flags (Avoid Cowboys)

items: **Can't provide Part P registration number** â€” Illegal for notifiable work
**No vehicle signage** â€” Professional electricians have branded vans
**Cash only, no receipt** â€” No comeback if work fails
**Won't explain the problem** â€” You should understand what's wrong
**Pressure to upgrade everything immediately** â€” Scare tactics
**Quote doubles after diagnosis** â€” Bait and switch tactic
**No insurance details** â€” Ask to see public liability insurance certificate
**Arrives intoxicated or smelling of alcohol** â€” Obvious safety risk

content.text: âš ï¸ Common scam: Fake emergency electricians quote Â£100 on phone, then claim 'additional safety work required' costing Â£500-Â£1,000 once on-site. Always get written quotes BEFORE work starts.

content.text: When to Call Power Company vs Emergency Electrician
**Call your power company (FREE) if:**

items: **Neighbours also have no power** â€” Network fault, not your wiring
**Main fuse (before your meter) has blown** â€” Power company's responsibility
**Overhead cables damaged** â€” Network operator's issue
**Street lights out in your area** â€” Widespread outage

content.text: **West Midlands power companies:**

items: **Western Power Distribution (WPD):** 0800 096 3080 (Birmingham, Solihull, Coventry)
**National Grid:** 105 (UK-wide emergency number)

content.text: **Call emergency electrician if:**

items: **Only your property affected** â€” Fault is in your wiring
**Problem is AFTER the meter** â€” Your responsibility
**Consumer unit/fuse box issues** â€” Internal wiring fault
**Specific circuit tripping repeatedly** â€” Wiring or appliance fault

content.text: What Certificates Should You Receive?
After emergency electrical work, your electrician MUST provide:
Minor Electrical Installation Works Certificate
For small jobs like replacing sockets, light fittings, or minor repairs. Confirms work is safe and complies with BS 7671 wiring regulations.
Electrical Installation Certificate

For notifiable work: new circuits, consumer unit replacement, work in bathrooms. Part P registered electricians can self-certify. Unregistered electricians must notify Building Control (you pay Â£200-Â£500 extra).
âš ï¸ No certificate = no proof work is safe. You'll need it for insurance claims, selling your house, or if anything goes wrong later.
FAQs About Emergency Electrician Costs

items.question: Can I negotiate emergency electrician rates?
items.answer: Limited room for negotiation on emergency rates â€” they're already set at a premium. However, you can ask: (1) Is the call-out fee fixed or negotiable? (2) Do they offer discounts for pensioners/NHS/military? (3) Can you wait until morning for standard rates? Some electricians reduce call-out fees for repeat customers or if the job ends up being larger than expected.

items.question: Do emergency electricians charge VAT?
items.answer: Yes, unless they're below the VAT threshold (turnover under Â£90,000/year). Always ask if VAT is included in the quoted price. VAT adds 20% to the total. Example: Â£200 + VAT = Â£240. Cash-only electricians who don't charge VAT are often evading tax â€” risky to use.

items.question: Should I get multiple quotes for emergency work?
items.answer: For true emergencies (fire risk, exposed wires, total power loss), no â€” call the first available registered electrician. For less urgent 'emergencies' (one circuit out, can wait a few hours), yes â€” call 2-3 electricians for quotes. Prices can vary by 30-50%.

items.question: What if the emergency electrician can't fix it on the spot?
items.answer: You still pay the call-out fee and hourly rate for diagnosis. If parts are needed or the job is too complex, they should: (1) Make it safe (isolate faulty circuit), (2) Provide a written quote for the full repair, (3) Schedule a return visit. Some electricians waive the call-out fee if you book them for the full repair.

items.question: Is home emergency cover worth it for electricians?
items.answer: Maybe. Home emergency insurance costs Â£40-Â£150/year and covers emergency electrical, plumbing, and heating. Pros: No emergency call-out fees, 24/7 availability. Cons: Often uses approved contractors only (not your choice), excess fees (Â£50-Â£100), may not cover all work. Worth it if you're in an older property or hate dealing with emergencies.

items.question: Can I do temporary fixes myself to avoid emergency costs?
items.answer: Limited safe DIY options. You CAN: reset tripped circuit breakers, unplug faulty appliances, turn off affected circuits at the consumer unit. You CANNOT safely: repair damaged wiring, replace consumer units, work inside sockets/switches while powered. Touching live electrics can kill you. When in doubt, call a professional.

items.question: How quickly will an emergency electrician arrive?
items.answer: Depends on demand and your location. Typical response times in 2026: Urban areas (Birmingham, Solihull): 45 mins-2 hours. Rural areas: 1-3 hours. Christmas/New Year: 2-6 hours (high demand). Some advertise '30-minute response' but this often means 'on the road within 30 mins' not 'arrived at your door'.
